The fellowship, an honour that recognised one person each year, aims to recognise civic societal values and positive work on shaping Singapore. On receiving it, Mr Lim took care to mention the role society is playing, and also the relevance of skills he believes are required in morning meetings held at the Presidential Office.
Creative problem-solving, integrity in public service, and good governance are attributes Mr Lim aspires to, and he hopes to develop these traits in everyone. In addition, he takes the time to reflect, slow down occasionally, listen, observe closely and tap into his feelings to analyze issues in-depth, to propose moderate, balanced solutions.

President Trump’s deliberations on the pay issue highlighted bitter internal disputes within his own administration over whether to follow through with this year’s pay increase or revive last year’s halt.
Earlier in his presidency, Mr. Trump ordered a raise for civilian employees as Congress had intended, and restricted the raises beyond a certain rank. But in 2020, Mr. Trump indicated he would not further negotiate it, forcing his personnel aides to seek a rollback through a rarely invoked statutory provision giving the president outright control over the raises. According to the effective date, if enacted it could actually reduce the pay scales even for the rest of 2019.

astronomers map-­out distant worlds with more and more preciseness, they are discovering other factors that play vital roles in determining if a world might support life. In the quest to find worlds that might be able to support life, astronomers now also have to consider the star the planet circles around and even the aspect of the former giant impacts put a planet into its current state.
For years, when astronomers looked at distant worlds, follow the water has seemed to be the rule of thumb as far as habitability goes. However, with deeper analysis and more precise information on the known planets, even though there may be water present in a planetary atmosphere, that doesn’t necessarily mean it could potentially host life.
To discover more life, astronomers will also have to look in the atmospheres of planets. These planets have atmospheres that contain molecules such as hydrogen, methane, oxygen and sulfur

Have Finns lost spending power?
The Finnish economy has soared over the last three years, boosted mainly by a sharp rise in wages. This means that Finnish consumers can now buy more, suggesting that their standard of living overall has increased. However, a growing number of Finnish consumers seems to believe that any increase in salaries will remain exceptional, writes Hufvudstadsbladet. This attitude is in turn leading to continued conditions of buyer’s misery. Instead of traditional thinking, it may be appropriate to prepare for less spending power in the future. This may be due to more flexible working hours allowing consumers to spend less freely, and more intense competition in the employment market which may push off growth of salary revenues . It’s even more important that you correctly address letters to individuals in a nonprofessional capacity. If you get this part wrong, you risk your letter sitting in your recipient’s mailbox.
A good practice is to “name drop.” If a person or department is listed on a company’s website’s “contact pages,” use that information. If you’re not sure who to send your correspondence to, check the company’s website for its “Contact Us” page or locate a staff directory. Other reliable resources include business guides such as the Better Business Bureau or others you have on hand, periodicals such as Worth magazine, and indexes such as Hoover’s Online of corporations headquartered near your home office. Some men get it easy no matter how tough on their bodies they are. Others have an extra helping of hair. One thing cannot be denied, though.
However hard a man tries to stop or delay the inevitable. Nature wins in the end. Fritz Olsen took a bolder than most approach and left science to design his effective treatment.
It used an injection given to male mice that showed significant results. Since then, public rumors grew as it was concluded that the injected male mice grew thicker hair with greater coverage. No further human study was done.

giving scientists more tools to track levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide over the entire planet and predict changes to the global climate.
A new paper details the methodology most scientists use to predict the world's carbon budget.
Researchers from the University of Pennsylvania, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and an international team of scientists led by Fan-Chi Lin, Alexander Hall Distinguished Professor in Geological Sciences, outline in the journal Nature Communications a method to readily convert CO2 emissions by the ocean, known as ocean sinks, into carbon dioxide, known as oceanic carbon storage, which is easily understandable by those who don't generally work in science. After hundreds of peer-reviewed papers, the methodology becomes uniform, a better conversion of empirical observations into decision-making and policy.

But while the vast majority of countries implement the system properly, several European capitals still make public funding for new cars and car purchase subsidies conditional upon manufacturers obtaining a so-called "certificate of conformity" or "abatement plans".
France is notable for not implementing the system, though it is now billed to comply at the end of 2012.

One of the play’s many invitations to re-consider the presentation of events through time is the depiction in one scene of 6 days as one may encounter on a daily basis with the word ‘yawm,’ or Day.
Yawm is said with an upward inflected accent (yawm). In Arabic, as in many Semitic languages, the words that form a derivation often retain the inflected forms of the original word as phonological elements within the new word. In this case, yawm, day, and jamá, evening, share the /j/ sound in the word sujúm, to gather, which originated from the similar sounding Sabiá, the Meccan locale where the pilgrimage is held monthly.

One day in the early 1970s, Tom Manion was sitting in San Francisco City Hall when five Catholic women started to pray inside the lobby, outside the mayor's office.
The women were there to protest low-income housing development. They spent nearly seven months fasting, some taking away all food and drink except for water during weekdays. Before they arrived, 15 protesters had gone to jail. They knew they were right- praying would express their desire- they had the numbers now. Hundreds showed up outside each day wherever prayed.
Manion said "People would come, they would look and pass by and then they look and say wait a minute what is that? Oh, there are people praying for five months and it doesn't look like they are out any time."

the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in 1886.
It was found by the crew of a cargo ship in 2003 and returned to the Dutch trader, who was delighted to learn it had survived so well.
Mr Spille was a corn broker, and left Holland at least eight times a year to collect freight to sell abroad.
On one of his last voyages he decided to become an unofficial beach comber. He filled the teardrop- shaped glass bottle and tossed it into the North ( or North Sea) with a view to any interesting contents washing up on any shore.
Around 120 years later his bottle and its message arrived on the shore of a Valencian village in Spain, pulled by careful hands from the sand by marine environmental charity, Asamblea del Mediterraneo.

professionals in both quantitative and qualitative analyses. Anyone who needs to make a big business decision can benefit from using a decision tree, whether an employee, salesperson or boss. There are two main ways they help you. A well-constructed mini-tree forms the basis for ongoing business planning, guiding subsequent decisions and actions. But since much important work is done at a more casual level via small trees as they pop out of and get solved through ordinary thought or dialogue, they do a great deal of the work themselves. (Used to build large trees, economics is perhaps the hardest financial discipline to easily convey in a list, so simple diagrams may be invaluable to explain certain economic ideas to others since the markings on a demand and cost curve correspond with particular tabular numbers.) alf Kudryavzev of the Russian Academy of Sciences in Moscow, have succeeded for the first time in studying a family of extragalactic radio sources at the highest possible wavelength. MIDDLETOWN, NJ - The Middletown Township Public Library and the Township of Middletown are pleased to announce the appointment of Kim Rinaldi as Provisional Library Director, beginning on February 15, 2022. This position pertains to the Library Division’s Section 102 demonstration program contained within Chapter 76 of Title 18 for appointment to work for an 18- to 30-month period, prior to appointment to work as Director without a term, continuing on an “at-will” basis. During this transitional period, a provisional library director’s salary is $129,900.
Ms. Rinaldi came to the Middletown Township Public Library from the Mountain View Library District in Colorado. WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican/senators and Democrats over funding.
Congressional Republicans have vowed to derail a planned increase in government borrowing authority this fall, setting a potential showdown over federal funding.
Lew said Sunday it makes no sense for Republicans to place a “time bomb” at Congress’s feet, where legislators and the nation could be reeling under the weight of a potential “government shutdown” while negotiating the spending cap.
“If there is a crisis ... the crisis will be of Washington’s own making and Congress needs to choose the path that helps the economy, helps jobs, helps those families who are struggling,” Lew told ABC’s “This Week” program.

The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend three days sharing an inside look at nine Black Friday "exclusive" products, according to a statement. Shoppers can purchase the products every 30 seconds or, alternatively, a 30-second commercial will run for every purchase. For retailers, this forces consumers to tune in immediately when deals are revealed because the products are then truly exclusive, thereby losing their buzz. On Monday, Nov. 24, consumers are in line to watch how Sally Jessica Raphael stylist Michael Cusamano picks his favorites from the "sexiest styles of the season" for Elle magazine.

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
From 2007-12, the US State Department approved sales to the UAE worth $ 11.8 billion, according to the latest estimate by the US Defense Security Cooperation Agency, the federal agency for processing foreign military sales and fostering international relationships.
The $ 2 billion orders in December brought 2012 foreign military sales to $ 36.8 billion after the US authorised $ 34.8 billion worth of deals for 2011 and $ 17.3 billion in 2010, according to DSCA figures. The orders related to the preceding five-year period.
The UAE previously was the world's sixth largest recipient of foreign military purchases in 2007, but its spending jumped to $ 6.7 billion in 2012 from $ 2 billion in 2011, DSCA

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to recast a re-election campaign narrative about the struggling economy into an agenda for America. He declared the nation is recovering, the sluggish recovery is his fault, and it's fair for advocates to expect that he — and Washington — can step in and get it humming faster.
Democrats who control both chambers of Congress had long seen the January set-piece public address as an opportunity to map out a legislative agenda for the next two years. In the recession, Republicans countered by using the address to highlight the nation's woes and to decry efforts to save or expand an inherited liberal agenda.
ButSpeffect of partisan speeches — as measured by public opinion surveys, cable TV ratings and in-person attendance — has been low.

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under which public and private fleets can get rebates of up to 25% up to $75,000 for each heavy-duty truck (over 26,000 pounds and less than 33,000 pounds), for replacing an older, higher-polluting Class 8 tractor with a 2010 and newer tractor that is a cleaner model.
Diesel repair facilities that install a qualified emissions control retrofit on a tractor no longer eligible for a truck replacement can recoup some of the money they invested, under this program.
The DERA program also authorizes funding for grants and assistance to state transportation agencies, nonprofits, local governments and fleets for projects such as replacing light-duty, medium and heavy-duty trucks with new engines meeting emissions limits

Graciousness might not seem like the most important thing in defining the success of a nation, but it is paramount for Mr Lim Siong Guan, the Institute of Policy Studies' fourth S R Nathan Fellow for the Study of Singapore.
Mr Lim is second Senior Minister of State for Law and Foreign Affairs, and a prime ministerial councillor at the Istana Review Panel, which advises the President, Lee Kuan Yew, on a wide range of national issues. The fellowship, an honour that recognised one person each year, aims to recognise civic societal values and positive work on shaping Singapore. On receiving it, Mr Lim took care to mention the role society is playing, and also the relevance of skills he believes are required in morning meetings held at the Presidential Office.
Creative problem-solving, integrity in public service, and good governance are attributes Mr Lim aspires to, and he hopes to develop these traits in everyone. In addition, he takes the time to reflect, slow down occasionally, listen, observe closely and tap into his feelings to analyze issues in-depth, to propose moderate, balanced solutions.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely.
Unsurprisingly, the United States of America also has some of the worst delivery records. One in four mothers will suffer injury during childbirth, and recent research suggests that up to a sixth may also die.
For the average American woman, the risk of dying from childbirth in the U.S.A. is more than twice that of women in Europe. This figure rises to more than three times higher women’s risk in the U.S.A. when compared with the vast majority of developing nations.
To tackle this problem would raise the bar of painful off-centre parenting experiences to levels previously unseen.

President Trump’s decision Monday to revive plans to freeze federal employee pay in 2020 and to institute a series of cuts to federal employee retirement programs was met with great consternation from stakeholder groups that represent the federal government’s two million civilian workforce.
President Trump’s deliberations on the pay issue highlighted bitter internal disputes within his own administration over whether to follow through with this year’s pay increase or revive last year’s halt.
Earlier in his presidency, Mr. Trump ordered a raise for civilian employees as Congress had intended, and restricted the raises beyond a certain rank. But in 2020, Mr. Trump indicated he would not further negotiate it, forcing his personnel aides to seek a rollback through a rarely invoked statutory provision giving the president outright control over the raises. According to the effective date, if enacted it could actually reduce the pay scales even for the rest of 2019.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers map-­out distant worlds with more and more preciseness, they are discovering other factors that play vital roles in determining if a world might support life. In the quest to find worlds that might be able to support life, astronomers now also have to consider the star the planet circles around and even the aspect of the former giant impacts put a planet into its current state.
For years, when astronomers looked at distant worlds, follow the water has seemed to be the rule of thumb as far as habitability goes. However, with deeper analysis and more precise information on the known planets, even though there may be water present in a planetary atmosphere, that doesn’t necessarily mean it could potentially host life.
To discover more life, astronomers will also have to look in the atmospheres of planets. These planets have atmospheres that contain molecules such as hydrogen, methane, oxygen and sulfur

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, tubular flowers which are followed by dark green moth-like fruits. For the gardener with limited space, and a sunny corner it is ideal.
The stiff stems emerge surprisingly young and at the same the little buds open. Like alpines, it’s easier to grow plants from seed, except diascias, when they flower in flushes and compete with one another. But don’t be put off as it is well worth working the stored seed into good sods in winter because, unless you want your diascias in pots, they are both cheap and lush in the heat of summer as they have no companions and don’t respond to water too much.
Established plants undergo a complete change as in springtime the upright stems become finer, bearing masses of tiny bright white five-lipped tubes that soon turn acid yellow,

Have Finns lost spending power?
The Finnish economy has soared over the last three years, boosted mainly by a sharp rise in wages. This means that Finnish consumers can now buy more, suggesting that their standard of living overall has increased. However, a growing number of Finnish consumers seems to believe that any increase in salaries will remain exceptional, writes Hufvudstadsbladet. This attitude is in turn leading to continued conditions of buyer’s misery. Instead of traditional thinking, it may be appropriate to prepare for less spending power in the future. This may be due to more flexible working hours allowing consumers to spend less freely, and more intense competition in the employment market which may push off growth of salary revenues . 1. Drew Griffin, the CNN investigative correspondent whose reporting made VA health care delays a national news story, told me that the VA ignored questions from reporters at their peril.

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a place for the family to relax and enjoy nature - but that's all ruined, according to Don Shell, who was in the area on Thursday.
Shell, who keeps his camper at the Turlock Village RV Park across the road, says he saw the ducks with the zipties and amped up his security on Thursday.
Shell went to action-type surveillance on foot after he saw the zipties on a lot full of extra-large meticil antifreeze bowls, presumably for decoying the ducks, he says.

September 2,2008: Hamas has an image problem, and it's getting worse. It's gotten so bad that the 30 year old son (Mosab Yousef) of one of the five members of the Hamas-aligned Sanabed clan who was assassinated in 1983 (as retribution by Israel) has decided to turn on Hamas and join the enemy. Mosab's story makes for one of the most riveting books I have ever read and is such a compelling look at contrasting worlds that it makes it very hard for anyone to not read it. A synopsis of the book was my recent blog entry "This Is Shameful." The fact is: Hamas is killing innocent Palestinians and luring them into their belief system. Abu Ghadiya was a character in the book, and I intend to write a separate entry (tomorrow?) about him, Zawiya and their activities. They are, succinctly, scum, and Bush was covering for them.

Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference.
About 8 percent of PCs in use run the Vista RTM release by Microsoft and about half of them are fitted with some form of high-definition multimedia support, such as support for Blu-ray DVDs or ATI Mobility RADE even, according to a keynote presentation Thursday at the four-day conference.
Microsoft’s Trustworthy Computing initiative was supposed to spur everyone to produce more secure products, but consumers are waiting, Gutmann said.
A number of high profile consumer video products, including Blu-ray optical drives, reports drive maker Nero AG, are so restricted by the various technical measures that they only work at application-throttled performance. HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound effect on Indian Country.
For several years, Congress mandated that each state or territory set up a comprehensive law enforcement database to compile information on missing persons locally, and issue lifetime alerts for those whose deaths are ruled to have been the result of foul play. The state Legislature mandated in 2015 for a database, but only dollars became available for a statewide alert system.
With money appropriated for the coming fiscal year, a pair of bills were considered by the Legislature’s Indian Affairs Committee, which includes House Democratic Leader Jenny Eck, to establish the missing persons and alert reporting systems. Eck is from Blackfeet Indian Reservation.
During the hearing, both tribes and county attorneys from state's seven jurisdictions spoke, emphasizing the need for the better reporting system.

If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism will soon become a 30-year saga. According to the Bush plan, it will end when we have managed to kill al Qaeda, to bring Osama bin Laden to trial, or to detain or eliminate the world's most wanted men. PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Coming functions will include location-based search and instant instant connections between two or more users such as video conference calls, mobile data services company Thinfos reckons.
“It will allow cellphones to work even if we’re not connected to a mobile base station as long as we know where we are,” Thinfos chief sales and marketing officer Francois Gisot said.
For example: A driver stuck on a Budapest overpass caught between a truck and a bus who requests help through the cellphone could get much-welcomed assistance before his battery gives out. Or you might be able to find the nearest sugar-and-sausage pork sausage stand.
Even as many GPS applications have indeed made it from the United States to European cellphones in the past year, Thinfos is only seeing their limits, like looking at a phone’s clock time or location when most need cellphone-based applications.

A neutrino event, identifiable by the rings of Cerenkov radiation that show up along the photomultiplier tubes lining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This method is based on the detection of the ultra-high-energy, sub-eV neutrinos, emanating from (yet unobservable) powerful cosmic accelerators. The study of the sources of this radiation gives physicists the hope to learn how multiple galaxies grow and evolve over eons of evolution only known in the past and to understand the nature and evolution of our own galaxy, The Universe, and its relation to our solar system.
What can you learn from this video: Methods to detect and analyse ultra-high energy neutrinos.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story.
ZeeMee is a new crowd-funded social media platform for students to use as trusted peer references to use along with their resumes on college admissions, scholarships, and fellowships applications. With ZeeMee, students can post videos, upload projects, and sign "love letters" to those who contributed positive items to a student's collection of activities and examples of their work.
Around the time that ZeeMee was launched, over 40 percent of the test scores used as part of college selection were false (flipped or points dropped or added erroneously). Jeannette Alvarez, the founder of ZeeMee says, "We believe it is time for the pendulum to swing back to where the teen's portrayals of self are equally as significant as GPAs and SAT and ACT scores. Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1877. A local news report from WBZ notes meteorologists are forecasting heavy rains for the Eastern Seaboard this weekend. So how can this be a meteorological puzzle?
Well, all of those extra rains fell here in July, according to a report from the state's Division of Ecological Restoration that was presented at the Thursday (Aug. 22) meeting of the Board of Registration for Foresters here at the Department of Conservation and Recreation here in Concord.
OK, maybe it's a somewhat different puzzle.
For years, the Division of Ecological Restoration has been tracking rainfall in rivers like the Sudbury, Assabet and Concord Rivers as a gauge for how dry -- or wet -- each river has become. Adding the extra rains of July has created a year with plenty of rainfall.

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 174.
For Americans with adjusted gross income of $100,000 or more the audit rate this year will be one out of every 40.
For taxpayers with over $10 million of adjusted gross income the audit rate is estimated to be about 17%. That means if an individual has an adjusted gross income of $10 million he will get audited about the same chance as a taxpayer that makes $100,000.

Courtesy Redwood City. On Monday, April 9, the city of Redwood City approved an ordinance allowing cannabis business only in the green zone on this map.
Redwood City is open for cannabis business. Well, sort of. The city has approved a new ordinance allowing only commercial agriculture in their green zone, currently home to, among other uses, pot farms and orchards. Redwood City joins other peninsula cities like San Bruno and Pacifica that also opened up their boundaries after regulating cannabis cultivation, sales, and delivery.
The Marin County Board of Supervisors just approved a cannabis retail tax program. At 10.25%, it will be the highest in the state and went into effect Jan 1, 2018. LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not increase the risk of cancer, according to the body of evidence currently available.
Citing “uncertainties in the evaluation,” the experts of the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the World Health Organization (WHO), concluded that there was “limited evidence” in humans and increased risks in animals.
Asked specifically about glyphosate’s new fifth-year WHO application waiting for approval, the Environment Ministry said it was worked on with close cooperation with the European Commission and was “ready to become the most extensive and comprehensive anti-pesticides instrument, which does not impose unnecessary restrictions on farmers and other users.”
FAO said the proposal by European farmer organisations was to ascertain the opposite: allow continued use of the world’s record-holder pesticide, Germany has told FAO in a letter dated April 29.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who's the only news director in Post-Crescent's longtime history, announced Tuesday that he plans to retire from full-time operations in early 2015, after adopting three new software programs.
Berthiaume, who said he's the paper's "adopted child," said he'll remain at POST-Crescent Media and act in an "an ambassadorial role" that includes helping to mentor the company's new newsroom technology efforts.
He said if the Post-Crescent leaves its current downtown building, the successor could face a problem attracting top-flight editors and managers because editors who do this kind of work is "very unusual" in smaller communities.

The Buzz: A piece of land off Hilltop Drive is getting cleared. Here's why.
Dirt, and lots of it — 107 truck lots-full to be exact — were being moved when City Times drove by this past Monday morning.
All that sand, asphalt, gravel and rock that was being dumped there off Hilltop Drive near Amado has one reason: the College at Palomar just cleared out all that land for a sports complex.
Enrique Garcia is refilling his nearby Hilltop truck with gravel so soil crash into the 10-foot dirt chasm he grown in his yard.
"The amount of traffic and access to view point will be double what it is now," Garcia said.

A failure to scan outsourced medical records has caused an approximate three- to five-month backlog at the Memphis Veteran Administration Medical Center, The Daily Caller has learned.
TheDC was exclusively given a 39-page long email sent to employees at the facility on Oct. 17 from chief of staff Dr. Diane Zarbo: “Since December, approximately 75,000 Contractor generated facsimiles from OIG referrals for outpatient records have been received, but scanning incomplete/not meeting all needs has resulted in a continuing backlog.”
The Department of Veterans Affairs has had multiple problems integrating its record keeping processes, including the awarding of a questionable $55 million no-bid contract to a Washington D.C.- based shell corporation in 2007 known as Inquilab Consulting Services Corp alongside a shady relationship with senior VA managers.
The company’s sole employee, Hyee Lee at the time, was indicted in August for misreporting billing information for the same filings.

Citizens from Australia, Japan and the United States already have to give the biometric information. All other travellers 14 and older are required to do so on an “interim” basis until biometric screening becomes mandatory across the country for every visa applicant in the year ahead.

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1989, one of the world’s largest food companies issued a press release announcing a major recall of eight products linked to a food-borne illness outbreak that resulted in 250,000 hospitalizations and 5,000 deaths.
Managing product quality and safety today is the most critical dimension of an organization’s overall supply chain management (SCM) strategy, according to Harvard Business Review. Unfortunately, supply chain disruptions including product defects and recalls force food and beverage enterprises to take a hard look at their procurement arrangements. The pressure to quickly fix a recall issue or manage a product shortage requires decision-makers build more resilient supply networks and more actively manage product quality risks. KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original Balinese and others in Indonesia fought side-by-side with the Javanese against the Islamic norm that swept eastwards. They resisted for more than a century the demands that they convert.
The tough fighting paid off, but only sustained by struggle of the Balinese, Javanese, Sasaks and others.
Associated Press photographer Dita Alangkara took a light trawler to the Kei Islands in eastern Indonesia and found islands allowing citizens to practice their religions freely, fighting a common enemy: The influx of Islam from the heart of Indonesia.

I am compelled to get the word out regarding a Senate bill that could adversely affect private preschools in California. The bill is labeled SB 837 or Kindergarten Readiness Act of 2014. In a nutshell, SB 837 makes methods to certify private day care teachers "subject to the criteria for admission for purposes of licensure in a municipal district of the California Community College System pursuant to Article 2 (commencing with Section 82040) of Chapter 2 of Part 55 of Division 7." This means that any and all private schools, nursery schools, child care facilities who employ teachers as sentinals for children's education, will be required to comply with State laws regarding experience, age, psychological and criminal background checks, etc as established in California Community College system under a certificate of proficient of excellent teaching. This particular bill was brought about by a trade organization known as Smart Start for California's Children.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. People don’t want to open and read a letter addressed to “Business Leadership,” but rather to the President, Vice President, or someone listed on your corporate website. It’s even more important that you correctly address letters to individuals in a nonprofessional capacity. If you get this part wrong, you risk your letter sitting in your recipient’s mailbox.
A good practice is to “name drop.” If a person or department is listed on a company’s website’s “contact pages,” use that information. If you’re not sure who to send your correspondence to, check the company’s website for its “Contact Us” page or locate a staff directory. Other reliable resources include business guides such as the Better Business Bureau or others you have on hand, periodicals such as Worth magazine, and indexes such as Hoover’s Online of corporations headquartered near your home office. Green Bay -- The Green Bay Packers have agreed to terms on a three-year deal with wide receiver James Jones, a source told the Journal Sentinel.
According to the source, QB Aaron Rodgers and WR Greg Jennings have already agreed on terms with the Packers as well, though there have yet to be any announcements from the team.
Rodgers signed a six-year extension while Jennings agreed to terms on a four-year package on April 6.
Jennings' deal is worth $40 million, which includes a $21.3 million signing bonus and $21 million guaranteed in the first year.
Jennings turned down substantially more money to join Chicago and has vibed about his decision apparently evidenced by the way he tackles fans who stand before Green Bay games in a championship ring hats modeled after the Bears' "Super Bowl Rings."
Jennings had said his intentions to stay with the Packers was rooted in faith and family. Jennings' younger brother, David, 17, lost two legs below the knee in an Oct. 4 house fire.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men get it easy no matter how tough on their bodies they are. Others have an extra helping of hair. One thing cannot be denied, though.
However hard a man tries to stop or delay the inevitable. Nature wins in the end. Fritz Olsen took a bolder than most approach and left science to design his effective treatment.
It used an injection given to male mice that showed significant results. Since then, public rumors grew as it was concluded that the injected male mice grew thicker hair with greater coverage. No further human study was done.
Early March 2012 finally saw the first documentation of human trials. Fifteen men began with a cause of baldness confirmed by dna analysis. They showed signs of a relationship with two female mice with strong hair growth.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear infections, bronchitis, and throat infections. It can also be used in combination with other medications to prevent heart infections, for the early stages of chlamydial infections in women, and for the infection caused by Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare infections.
Clarithromycin helps to keep up the overall level of the good bacteria in your vagina and internal passage and can help prevent infections when taken daily for the long term. Your health care provider will likely prescribe this medicine for at least 6 months for treatment. Talk to your doctor about this.
Each pink, round, biconvex tablet with AV200 on one face and a bisect of the code AV02 on the other face contains 200 mg of clarith

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to track levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide over the entire planet and predict changes to the global climate.
A new paper details the methodology most scientists use to predict the world's carbon budget.
Researchers from the University of Pennsylvania, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and an international team of scientists led by Fan-Chi Lin, Alexander Hall Distinguished Professor in Geological Sciences, outline in the journal Nature Communications a method to readily convert CO2 emissions by the ocean, known as ocean sinks, into carbon dioxide, known as oceanic carbon storage, which is easily understandable by those who don't generally work in science. After hundreds of peer-reviewed papers, the methodology becomes uniform, a better conversion of empirical observations into decision-making and policy.

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised (without the need for a $20,000 X-ray machine) to show you your secret friends walking behind you, but they never really lived up to the promise for kitting out uninvited, un-X-ray-able peeping toms with the ability to laser-like X-ray vision.
Now, a major breakthrough by French scientist Denis Benjamin has a real shot at a comic-style X-ray machine: and no eye-patch and hat are required to do the honors. He presents an adaptable software tool that, by offsetting two images of the same object, can decipher and zoom-in to hidden, internal structures – such as blood vessels or bone-soft tissue elements – that would normally remain invisible if captured by conventional X-ray equipment.

Take into account the coming interview: “Being prepared means understanding not only what our own job description is, but also what talent is needed for other jobs that we may need to transition to in the future. BURBANK — Granada Hills resident Bob Kalaba found a new best friend in a Labrador mix named Iggy, whom he adopted Saturday at the Burbank Animal Shelter.
Iggy playfully ran to greet Kalaba while jumping high and looking for affection from a volunteer. Women, especially young women, tend to call in to procure animals at the shelter’s PetMatch program, said Renay Excel, an AmeriCorps national volunteer. Since a boy’s best friend is his dog, she said men observed lack of consolidation as they drove to the shelter, and sought to patch this imbalance related to relinquished, orphaned and stray animals.
More than 25 women did call to adopt at the shelter Saturday, she said.
“There’s a hit list of about 10 women, because they keep calling to adopt, adopt, adopt,” Excel said.
The PetMatch program called women without children to foster animals to reduce the overpopulation and ease the shelter’s burdens, since dogs thrived more in a home setting than in the shelter, Excel added.

HELENA, Mont. — U.S. Rep. Greg Gianforte is pinning his third campaign in two years on Montana residents being better off economically since President Donald Trump took office and that the voters will give him credit for the effort.
Gianforte told Montana Public Radio on Tuesday he is confident in his re-election and vast improvements in hard-to-refute economic indicators like low unemployment and a booming stock market.
However, he criticized a familiar fault – the gap in economic development between Montana and the rest of the country.
Trump campaigned for Gianforte last week in Bozeman, Billings and Great Falls to highlight the billionaire Republican’s record on employment and affordability and their plans for redressing poverty and rural economic opportunities extended throughout the United States.

The Financial Post’s Geoff Zochodne did a sweep of the big banks’ economists on Oct. 1 and found that the received wisdom now is that the Bank of Canada will quicken its march to a more accommodative policy stance than originally planned.
All but one of the economists expects midrates in March of next year of less than 1%. In November the overnight money rate averaged just under 1% and in October it averaged between 1% and 1.1%. For the big banks, Thursday’s statement by the BCR board means an imminent curtailing of quantitative easing and a move towards tighter monetary stance. As of now, the last day the rate could be dropped to zero has not been set, but analysts believe, based on the heavy volume they are expecting in dealer markets on Thursday, that this cut will almost certainly occur Thursday afternoon, immediately before the bank’s interest rate announcement.

McChord, who started the online security company Datto in 2007 in his father's basement, will step down as CEO.
McChord, who started the online security company in 2007 in his father's basement, said he will step down to focus on his family and on personal projects.
"After more than a decade as CEO of Datto LLC, the team and I have reached an agreement to transition me out of this role so I can serve my family and focus time on personal pursuits," he said in a statement.
The Norwalk-based company's past board members Rick Smith and Frank Bisignano will become co-CEO of Datto Holdings Inc., the company's publicly held parent company.
McChord thanked the company's executives and employees, and added that there "will never be another company like Datto -- what an honor to be part of history in building a business that will shape the computing landscape for years to come."
New leader Petro Quartermaine started with Datto as a desktop support engineer, and was promoted to chief product officer last year.

The cryptocurrency craze is reaching frenzied levels as 2017 draws to a close.
Barely in the cents when trading was started at the beginning of this decade, the price of Bitcoin on Jan. 1, 2009 was nearly eight cents (4.9 pence). It was trading up to a meager $1 the following year.
Since then, the price has surged as cryptocurrencies have become a hot and controversial investment choice, caught in a volatile swing of both wild speculation and deep skepticism because their use raises important policy questions that many find hard to resolve.
Many governments are troubled about the cross-border anonymous movement of money on the peer-to-peer or deeper blockchain technology that has emerged as a way to record and secure entries on individual's cryptocurrency holdings. Also jarring big picture, in general, is that people are turning to digital tokens with no physical form, proponents say.

Ronald B. Lund, 64 years old, died suddenly in his home, July 22, 2013. He was bon in Taunton, son of the late Melvin and Natalie ( Hammond) Lund. Ron leaves his wife, Patricia (Ranieri ). He was an electrician for Coyle Electric. He also worked for Perego Construction, Meyers Brothers, Davey Tree Company, and he owned Lund Electric. He served honorably in the Army. He was a communicant of the Church of Jesus on Chestnut St., Brockton. He was on the Board of Directors, Boxing Committee for the Boys Club of Brockton, a member of the Kiwanis Club, Director of COOP Electric and a member of the Brockton Lions Club. He was fun loving and easy going and loved life. He was a devoted husband and father, “Paw Paw” and great grandfather.
He was grandfather of 15, great grandfather of 6, brother-in-law, and his friends were infinite.

The total VR market will generate $5.1 billion this year, new report claims.
2016 is poised to be the year that virtual reality really gets going, as Oculus Rift, PlayStation VR and HTC Vive all hit the market in earnest.
That, according to SuperData Research, based in New York. In a new report, it claims the worldwide ecosystem for VR will bring in a total of $5.12 billion in 2016, up some 4,000 percent over 2015. How much of that is pure VR revenue versus VR along with PC video game revenue isn’t clear, though of course there is cross-over.
Closely following VR are mobile free-to-play and mobile downloadable game emulators and clones, at $3.3 billion. The one area appear to be hurt is console-based digital games. Brandon Ewing, 24, of the 3700 block of South Alsdorf Avenue, was charged with first-degree murder in the Oct. 15 slaying of Jackey Townsend, a prosecutor said yesterday during a bonds hearing at the Leighton Criminal Court building.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer has always been one of my great heroes of the faith. Such appreciation, of course, hardly makes me distinct. Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis almost from the start, and was himself executed as a traitor to the Third Reich (1945), is well loved. In all my reflections on this increasingly esteemed figure, however, I have struggled just to grasp what he might tell us as disciples of Jesus on spiritual formation today. CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Abd Allah was arrested on Saturday from his office at Cairo Airport, the sources said, adding that the book was incomplete and its title would soon be changed on its cover.
Abd Allah has denied there was any inaccuracy or the book contained false information, according to a statement his wife posted on his private Facebook account after hearing he had been arrested, his wife's statement added.
Omar Khairy Wan Jaffar, author of another book critical of Egypt's economy published recently by the same author, denied all charges and refused to accept an apology in a televised appearance at his lawyer's office on Friday.
"I will return to work at Cairo International Airport. Egyptian security see security with writing books," Khairy told Sada al-Balad television last month. Both authors have written for the state-run news site El-Watan.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know the company and what skills and positive traits make you the right person for it. You'll also want to give an example of a time when you used these skills and were successful. Your response to this kind of question should not be short -- around five to 10 minutes may be too short if you name the skills that the position requires and illustrate how you successfully accomplished each one.
Employers always ask behavioral questions designed to discover how you deal with problems and challenges. During this time of economic uncertainty, expect to hear this question. How do you deal with a tight budget? How do you balance excellence with cost reduction? How do you come to grips with 25 employees loosing their jobs? If you can't handle tough issues, your employer won't understand how you are fit for the position you are interviewing for.

Antarctica New Zealand welcomes the Government’s Antarctic initiatives in Budget 2017 to maintain New Zealand’s ongoing presence and scientific research programme in Antarctica.
Antarctic science drives our science, scientific leadership and a high quality end-product by supporting New Zealand’s long term commitment to international collaboration in science.
Block grants are welcome. A programme with a reliable financial base for Antarctic science enables us to initiate programmes that draw international partners, as we have done through our Development Science Platform programme with the University of Auckland and Te Puni Kokiri which converted understandings of traditional knowledge into environmental change and evolution.
We welcome the government’s commitment to extending the Christchurch-Antarctica air service through 2019-2021. This strengthens New Zealand’s access, both for personnel to and on-the-ground delivery and logistics through aviation infrastructure. This is critically important for New Zealand’s ability to get people and equipment to our bases in Antarctica.

Rita, 35, a Christian, was married for an arranged match, and after a normal birth she gave birth again to a child without health problems.
She now has to spend a day without food to thank God for the blessing of a third and final baby, since authorities in her village Haryana in northern India say they will gradually refuse any new applications for a domestic "surrogate mother" (woman placed to bear children for another couple).

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting national regulations without going through a EU-wide green light process.
But while the vast majority of countries implement the system properly, several European capitals still make public funding for new cars and car purchase subsidies conditional upon manufacturers obtaining a so-called "certificate of conformity" or "abatement plans".
France is notable for not implementing the system, though it is now billed to comply at the end of 2012.
On top of that, the Danish energy ministry recently told the EUobserver that it would review the national car purchasing subsidy system at the end of 2012 because inconsistency between EU and national rules.

State lawmakers greenlined a similar bill last year, but it wasn't signed by then-Gov. John Hickenlooper. Hickenlooper left office in January, while the legislature recessed midway through last week, when he signed the measure.
"A number of common business practices among the licensed businesses would not be taxed under a financial services system..."
The law took effect on Jan. 12, but Hickenlooper issued an executive order last month opening the program back up to those who hadn't applied. The new rules waived a $1,000 barrier to entry to the system, according to KUSA 9NEWS.

The Maryland teenager who terrorized his high school used his father's handgun to shoot a girl he'd just broken up with and another classmate, investigators said Wednesday.

According to court documents, Rollins approached 15-year-old Brianna Benlolo in the school's courtyard, put the 9mm handgun in her face and fired.
He then kept firing at 14-year-old Jaelynn Willey before going back to Benlolo to kill her. Willey survived, but her injuries led to an intestine transplant.
The assault was captured on security cameras and Rollins was apprehended at his home in Frederick. A .380 pistol, bulletproof vest and $1,176 were found in his room, police said.

Labyrinths of Memory (Matahat El-Zakirah) play will be performed several times over three days at Osiris art space, the same location that hosted the play in December 2015.
One of the play’s many invitations to re-consider the presentation of events through time is the depiction in one scene of 6 days as one may encounter on a daily basis with the word ‘yawm,’ or Day.
Yawm is said with an upward inflected accent (yawm). In Arabic, as in many Semitic languages, the words that form a derivation often retain the inflected forms of the original word as phonological elements within the new word. In this case, yawm, day, and jamá, evening, share the /j/ sound in the word sujúm, to gather, which originated from the similar sounding Sabiá, the Meccan locale where the pilgrimage is held monthly.

Nearly 50 years of protests, lawsuits and ballot battles over low-income housing have made San Francisco a nationwide model for efforts to keep urban America from becoming home to only the very rich or the very poor.
One day in the early 1970s, Tom Manion was sitting in San Francisco City Hall when five Catholic women started to pray inside the lobby, outside the mayor's office.
The women were there to protest low-income housing development. They spent nearly seven months fasting, some taking away all food and drink except for water during weekdays. Before they arrived, 15 protesters had gone to jail. They knew they were right- praying would express their desire- they had the numbers now. Hundreds showed up outside each day wherever prayed.
Manion said "People would come, they would look and pass by and then they look and say wait a minute what is that? Oh, there are people praying for five months and it doesn't look like they are out any time."

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his first back-to-back appearances at congressional hearings in his four years at the Fed, Powell addressed the lower house banking committee where Republican representatives sought assurances the US central bank was not on a path to damaging rates too high ahead of last year’s midterm elections.
They also questioned whether higher interest rates, while reassuring that the economy remains strong, would spur a financial crisis.
In several hours of questioning, committees on financial services focused largely on the US fiscal outlook and whether Fed rate increases pose a threat to the wellbeing of the country’s wealthiest. A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in 1886.
It was found by the crew of a cargo ship in 2003 and returned to the Dutch trader, who was delighted to learn it had survived so well.
Mr Spille was a corn broker, and left Holland at least eight times a year to collect freight to sell abroad.
On one of his last voyages he decided to become an unofficial beach comber. He filled the teardrop- shaped glass bottle and tossed it into the North ( or North Sea) with a view to any interesting contents washing up on any shore.
Around 120 years later his bottle and its message arrived on the shore of a Valencian village in Spain, pulled by careful hands from the sand by marine environmental charity, Asamblea del Mediterraneo.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to their website owners at any capacity possible. Many resellers make enough profit to support their families and move to more expensive business neighborhoods all within a few short years.
Numerous software applications and solutions, along with other tools suitable for website builders, have emerged in recent years. While many of these websites cater toward new site builders with little techical experience, sites pulled together mostly by those with more experience -- such webmasters, blog owners and e-commerce store owners -- exist. When these high-energy site owners are unable to modify or maintain their server space, the owner turns to a control panel solution. Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy produced in Earth’s interior. It is thought that primordial energy comes from radioactive elements that are created late in Earth’s formation.
Recent studies estimate Earth’s energy budget, by narrowing down the power consumption and production of magma, faults and the core via reconciling how much energy Earth must be getting to have a magnetic field, plate tectonics and future volcanoes. The five largest sources for the energy consumption are the area around mid latitude plate boundaries, the core, upper mantle and crust, deep mantle and asthenosphere, and upper mantle and asthenosphere. (CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a problem inside the animal before the cancer started.
Whether that information eventually helps fight cancer in public remains to be seen, but the story is already playing an important role in explaining elephant biology. Animal DNA does not encode proteins like humans and other mammals do; it carries genetic information in a different form. Finding out how the animal repurposed the information could lead to new drug responses.
“That mesenchymal stem cell will make an incredible public nuisance mitigating cancer,” team biologist Vaughn Ackerman said in a statement. The remarkable ability of the elephant to destroy cells with cancer that may go undetected would also be useful to other groups of scientists concerned with cancer biology.

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemical herbicides, reduces waste, and allows soil to be healthier overall. To achieve optimal decomposition with large amounts of waste, though, you need the right place for your compost bin and equipment large enough to hold all elements needed to process yard waste.
Check your municipality’s regulated practices. If you live near a city or town, you may need a permit from the state to operate as a composter. Your !cleanhme! contractor can also help determine local regulations for setting up the compost bin.
Commercial-sized compost bins tend to come in two material styles so you’ll have different options based on which material can best suit your needs. Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't tracking your spending as well as you could, inefficiencies may be sneaking into your supply chain, reducing your effectiveness as a company and possibly diminishing profits.
One of the ways to reduce errors and get a better feel of how businesses are performing is how many production facilities actively seek to develop "lean accounting."
Getting clear numbers
One of the best ways to develop any good practice in supply chain management — or financial operations more broadly — is to know how subjective your understanding of the ins and outs is and work to improve on that. When it comes to lean accounting, the goal is to place as much importance on numbers as possible, allowing manufacturers and distributors to put less stock - as it were - into accounting measures that aren't realistic.

"Country Music Hair" author Erin Duvall breaks down the 'dos.
You can't think about country music without thinking about hair. Whenever anyone talks about Dolly Parton, her look is mentioned in the first sentence. You can’t think about the history of country music, or its future, without considering the role of its hair, both high-maintenance glam (Patsy Cline, Reba) and shabby, down-home (Gram Parsons, Jamey Johnson), wild (Miranda Lambert, Willie) or lean (Trisha Yearwood, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers). Country music’s hair has style and history (can ve back 40 or more years on most any looks). An album cover is often judged by how the band should look, with major labels hoping to capitalize on Nashville's long-standing connection with hair care companies. And many discussions of country music's history regard a musician’s hair’s shape and length as an almost fundamental way to summarize their persona.
But why is that? Erin Thorpe Duvall

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals in both quantitative and qualitative analyses. Anyone who needs to make a big business decision can benefit from using a decision tree, whether an employee, salesperson or boss. There are two main ways they help you. A well-constructed mini-tree forms the basis for ongoing business planning, guiding subsequent decisions and actions. But since much important work is done at a more casual level via small trees as they pop out of and get solved through ordinary thought or dialogue, they do a great deal of the work themselves. (Used to build large trees, economics is perhaps the hardest financial discipline to easily convey in a list, so simple diagrams may be invaluable to explain certain economic ideas to others since the markings on a demand and cost curve correspond with particular tabular numbers.) Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, in Myanmar's Kachin state, injuring more than a dozen people underneath a local karaoke shop.
Fears grew that some 20 people may have been buried under almost two metres (six feet) of rock, boulders and soil, but the jade-rich region was cut off to the outside world by roadblocks and tight restrictions on independent media.
Police Lieutenant General Tun Kyi said on Sunday the missing people are likely to be trapped under shrubby vegetation wind-blown from surrounding mountain ranges, exasperating the search effort.
"I think they are probably stuck in thick underground bushes, under stones and foreign bodies," he said in a phone interview, adding that heavy machinery has been unsuccessful. "This extends the timeline of finding missing people."

Four oil spill sites in Nigeria identified by the UN, which Shell has claimed to have had cleaned up by contractors since 2011, are still polluted, says a report by Amnesty.
One of the worst pollution cases in human history, 13 former Shell oil wells in the Niger Delta are still leaking, it says.
Shell refuses to hand over to government the names of the Nigerian contractors responsible.
Shell says 27 wells were cleaned between 2011 and 2012.
There are 35 spill locations in a typical Shell well, according to one former Shell manager.
The UN oil spill report, which examined satellite images, PX findings and ground surveys, concluded it spotted four wells still leaking oil since 2011 - and a further 12 wells not cleaned earlier.
"Shell should stop dismissing its obligation to report on environmental impairments with boilerplate disclosure," Amnesty said.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp. Unfortunately, when version became recently available for Lightroom on the web, it turned out not to be particularly useful for many photographers. You still had to graft layers over your images, and even then the results were disappointing at times. Furthermore, if you squinted only an eighth-of-a-second at the fill, it tended a bit karstic when compared to the real thing. Well, Lightroom CC is bet devoted to making the adjustment healing tool even more useful, by adding content aware fill for the web (including third party plug-ins). This makes it much easier for raw shooters who rely on the AdobeRAW generator in Lightroom to save .XMP amends without having to revert to unfamiliar programs like Photoshop or Photoshop Fill. The Waste Land as an iPad app demonstrates how we might re-imagine the book, but it also illustrates how editorial choices can limit value.
The Guardian recently documented a June trek of 25 people through T. S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, on the App Store under the category ‘poems’ (see map). As would be expected, the poem’s language can be challenging, stylistically broken. Yet microfiction author and Web consultant Esther Gwendolyn Bénintendi has demonstrated that a webtext can, indeed, exist in an app-based environment.
Readers, mirrored in ebooks (with added hyperlinks), have the pleasure of being part of – albeit in microcosm – a growing and emerging literary web where books, meanings, contexts, histories, imaginaries, authors and losses have profitable open possibilities.

His craftspeople expertly teased out dimpled brick, old-school block and steel beams, curving sections of the interior wall.

The Sockers' postgame championship trot around the field at the Sports Arena and the trophy looked familiar, but this title was different.
This time, 25 players raised their hand with grit-teeth smiles to receive their award as San Diego Sockers try of the year atop their championship shirt: echoes of the five years regardless of the three as they clasped placards to their chest that proclaimed, "We Are Legion."
If there is any sentimentality in these awards, it's the legacy of this team – a family that has endured five championships, swept through the league like wounded lions, sent opponents cowering in silence and charged across fields and fields, a regiment of warriors that backed each other to the death, banding together against all adversity and all odds because the sole weakness is among them.
One last group of trophies, one glorious last winner's trip, one final puff of faux smoke because, yes, we are legion … because five is not a number.

Western diplomats have refrained from singling out the new site and did not include it on a report they released in June that raised red flags over Tehran's ongoing nuclear activities.
President Donald Trump has repeatedly said he would take military action if necessary to ensure that Iran does not become a nuclear power. If the U.S. or Israeli forces attempt any similar strikes on the site, the depth of the blast — combined with geography — makes the site a dangerous target despite the fact that it is too remote to affect Tehran's nuclear plans under the 2015 agreement with world powers.

Who is Sherlock Holmes? Such is the question posed this summer by Jeffrey Hatcher’s play Holmes and Watson, the final production of the Alley Theatre’s 17-18 season, but it’s also the issue raised by the character and his many inventions—such as abstention from alcohol, resolution of conflict through rigorous intellectual dialog, and its quasi-scientific, secular worldview .
So, who is Sherlock Holmes? A fictional character from a long-running Victorian-era series of short stories and novels, to be sure, but more recently adapted for theatre and cinema than every before and borrowing the canonical interpretation that Holmes is an entirely rational and technically-inclined thinker working unhampered by error, circumstance, or imagination under extraordinary fortuitous conditions. Star Washington Wizards guard Gilbert Arenas, 28, appeared in the D.C. Superior Court to be sentenced for the gun crime he admitted to in January. He has been spared a jail term.
In a plea deal, Arenas had agreed to plead guilty just to get the gun charge. Prosecutors recommend less than a two-year jail term, the Washington Post reported Wednesday.
Judge Robert E. Morin Wednesday gave Arenas a one to two-year suspended sentence, which will count in his favor if “he will be involved in an irresponsible act” involving guns again, Arenas attorney, Lloyd L. Metzger, told the Washington Post.
Arenas still faces the other gun charge, one federal count of carrying a firearm outside the home for an illegal purpose. That case is yet to be heard.

Participants answered six questions regarding their knowledge of each subject area. It was found that college graduates tended to outperform non-college graduates. SAN FRANCISCO — The outgoing chair of the California GOP — the nation’s largest state Republican Party — has issued a dire warning that his state represents “the canary in the coal mine” for the party‘s future.
Jim Brulte wrote an open letter to the political conventions of his home state’s four congressional districts, held after June’s midterm elections to pick the local GOP’s U.S. representatives. All four seats are held by Republicans, but each exhibits another kind of tribal alignment. While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of scam tactics during tax season when people need to make good decisions and file their returns on time.
Filed identity theft complaints almost always complain about how hard it is to prove when a fraudulent return has been filed in their names.
The scam attacks are also taking new twists as scam emails are claiming to be from the IRS. These faux emails can also attempt to download malware that slows the operating system to a halt. Phishing attacks can use similar tactics that steal personal data, but in the cases that involve scammers impersonating a business, the intent usually is to attempt a fraud, the IRS says.

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that Beijing couldn’t beat San Francisco at its own game, but China doesn’t function in quite the same way the U.S. does when it comes to business, and that’s not necessarily a failure.
Uber, led by CEO Travis Kalanick, obviously decided that the Chinese market was the place that it could make the most money and impact, and China has a larger overall bicycle market than all of the other global markets combined. Investors have spent $17 billion on Asia so far this year, but Uber reported this week that tide is turning for them abroad. Instead of spending all of their time resolving a massive pedestrian complaint, or a strike, or whatever class action suits are lining up, Kalanick knows his best bet for taking down Lyft is putting a halt on investments in pointless businesses internationally.

The attacks, in which flooding the victims' computer screen with pop-ups and demanding payment to use them before they were contaminated with the malicious software, started Sunday.
On Sunday, the blacklist website was still able to verify if any Internet browsers on the Haitongct.net domain were infected. By Tuesday, the site showed only a black page that couldn't access further.
It is unclear who is behind such attacks, but the blacklisting business is lucrative. Security software firm RSA estimates the popularity and scale of pay-per-install scams – including blacklists – topped $125 million last year. Most of the websites are run by gangs in the former Soviet Union, RSA researchers say.

Insight: Did Conficker help sabotage Iran's nuke program?
(Reuters) - A cyber warfare expert claims he has linked the Stuxnet computer virus that attacked Iran’s nuclear program in 2007 to a cat-and-mouse battle in the Internet-era that began in March 2007, with emails that show government-controlled military networks in China, United States, France, England, and Spain all tracking each other and communicating in real time, preparing for what ultimately became Stuxnet.
I don't know enough about this to know whether or not Stuxnet is the so-called cyberweapon we've been hearing about that suffers no human controls and is invisible unless you build a special machine to listen and record the data.
Further reading: Slashdot has also been following the story.

The transaction is scheduled to close in June, following approval from the YCIDA's Board of Directors.

Growing up on Chicago’s North Side, “Rocky” Yamanaka recalled few incidents of racism. “Me and my sister were the only Japanese. But we were curiosities to most of the Caucasian kids,” he said.
Racism more often arose in his teenage years. He encountered it in a summer work assignment in Los Angeles where the restaurant manager routinely called him “sonofabitch” or “sonofagun” in front of customers because Yamanaka often arrived late from his home in Tujunga, Calif., a suburb of LA.
“It was always, ‘Why didn’t they name the restaurant Sam Yamanaka’s Tuna and Bean Pies,’ Poor Yemanaka,” said Rick, who is the chef/owner of Rick’s Swirl Bar & Grill in San Francisco’s Bernal Heights neighborhood. “No one ever was mad at him, or angry with him even.”

The end of the text depicts violent behavior.
The text says cancel the date.
You do that right? Because he’s dangerous. Domestic violence doesn’t mean for your looks.
Hundreds more women across America will be subject to an unhealthy relationship just like my girlfriend Diane.
Nearly two million women in America will suffer the effects of domestic violence, abuse or rape this year.
To be strong enough to leave.
Women must know that they have the right and the wherewithal to leave in commitment, power, and money aren’t the motivation in taking that step.

INDIANAPOLIS — Eli Lilly will get more than $7 million in tax relief from the City of Indianapolis over the next decade.
The Indianapolis City-County Council approved Monday night about $7.1 million of tax abatements over 10 years to support the major refurbishment to its downtown headquarters.
An additional $26.7 million for jobs and economic growth will be allotted to another company, to further encourage the incoming national health care giant to put up their headquarters here.
Mayor Joe Hogsett said in a statement it's a "win-win" for the city looking toward the future.
Indianapolis is a national leader in bioscience, technology and life sciences and Lilly's investment will further these and other sectors and position the City for success," said Mayor Joe Hogsett.
The company's proposed move from its former Indy headquarters will give the city another full-throttle biomedical campus that will support and invigorate commercial, tourism, film and fashion.

However, the minister said the army restored control of the area around the airstrip located near the Royal Jordanian Air Force Base, and the Interior Ministry, which monitors the blasts, is conducting a very limited investigation to discover what caused this case, but did not announce it.

Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing most life on the nearby planet. The types of events that would cause explosions similar to those seen elsewhere would be nearly unthinkable to the people who inhabit our home star system in the 2260s.
But things change as you go forward in time. LinkedIn has responded to criticism of its "social ads" feature over its use of members' names and photos in advertisements on its website.
Many LinkedIn members have complained that the use of their details in this way has gone "beyond privacy grounds".
LinkedIn has now said it plans to test an alternative "contextual" advertising model.
"Target increases the opportunity for advertisers to appear on relevant content," LinkedIn said in a statement.
It added it had asked members for their permission to use their details.
Some 15 million LinkedIn users may be affected by the decision to reject members' ability to opt-out. Users accepted when registering on the site that user data is used for search-engine-like purposes. But they can now choose not to have them used specifically for advertising.
The firm stressed that both current and potential members can choose to have their names not displayed and picture or location information used in content on the social network.
Law firm Ifan Bradley & contribution writer Lee-Jvan Ross said members should argue for "profile privacy settings to be switched off for the usage of that data".
